MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prison Sentence of Irish Citizen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Begley Mr. Begley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the steps he has taken with regard to the situation of an Irish citizen (details supplied) who is currently serving a prison sentence in Dartmoor following representations made by Deputies; and if he will state: (a) the date which he made representations, if any; (b) the response he has received to date; (c) the date on which he received such response; and (d) the further steps he intends to take in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: The Irish citizen in question was arrested in January 1985 and is currently serving a three year and nine month sentence for assault. Written representations were made on behalf of the prisoner by the Irish Embassy to the prison authorities on 4 August 1986. These were followed by discussions with the assistant Governor of the prison on 1 and 17 September.

The prison authorities informed us by letter on 20 August and in the subsequent discussions that they are prepared to consider an application from the prisoner for alternative work should he decide to apply. The Irish Embassy has written to the prisoner and to his family informing them of the representations made and of the response received. The Embassy will continue to pursue the matter with the prison authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Lemass Mrs. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the type of security being used by the Passport Office to ensure against falsification of passports for drug traffickers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: As will be appreciated I am not at liberty to go into all the measures we take to ensure against falsification of Irish passports by drug traffickers or indeed any other criminal elements. The Deputy's attention is drawn to two very significant developments which have been introduced in recent years and which will ensure such falsification is rendered extremely difficult.

The first was taken in December 1984 when the scheme of identification in Garda stations already in use in the rest of the State, was extended to Dublin. This scheme helps to prevent false applications and thus ensures that passports issued in the State get into the right hands from the beginning.

The second step was taken in January 1985 with the introduction of the new Irish passport. Special attention was given to security in the design of this passport. The result is a passport of a very high standard which cannot easily be tampered with.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Briscoe Mr. Briscoe
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the conventions affecting human rights which exist under the auspices of the United Nations; to which of these Ireland is a signatory; to which conventions we have not as yet signed; and the reason in each case where we are not signatories.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy in respect of United Nations instruments in the field of human rights is contained in the following table:
United Nations Instruments in the field of Human Rights

row.entry: 1. Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide
2. International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination
3. International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights
4. International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights
5. Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights
The question of the Optional Protocol is being examined in the context of the consideration being given to the ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
6. Convention on the Non-Applicability of Statutory Limitations to War Crimes and Crimes Against Humanity

The decision not to proceed to ratification of this Convention. which has to-date been signed or ratified by only 29 states, has been taken because of concern on legal grounds at certain of the elements contained in the Conventions. No Western European state has signed or ratified this Convention.
7. International Convention on the Supression and Punishment of the Crime of Apartheid
With our partners in the Twelve we consider aspects of this instrument to be unacceptable both on legal and policy grounds and it is not proposed to sign or ratify the Convention.
8. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women
9. Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment

Careful consideration is being given to the changes in domestic law which would be necessary to permit ratification of this Convention, with which Ireland was prominently associated during its passage through the General Assembly.
10. International Convention against Apartheid in Sports
Because of concern at the legal, including possible constitutional, implications of certain of its articles it is not envisaged that Ireland will sign this Convention.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if the USA formally or informally requested the Irish Government to consider US bases in Ireland in the last four years; if so his response; if the USA has surveyed or requested surveys of Cork/Shannon or made any moves that might be construed as such in order to establish the military viability of such places as bases; if the USA has asked for or been granted facilities for any form of any communications systems on the west or south coasts of Ireland; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: The agreement between Ireland and the US in relation to immigration preclearance at Shannon permits

“the installation and operation of such communications and inspection aids and equipment as the Immigration and Naturalisation Service requires and as are agreed by the competent authorities of Ireland as being necessary for preinspection”.

Any facilities for communications therefore are strictly limited to the requirements of the preclearance operation. I am not aware of any other requests for communications facilities and as regards the other issues raised by the Deputy I am not aware of any requests from the US authorities nor of activities of the type to which the Deputy refers.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the discussions which the Irish Government have had with the USA and/or UK Governments in relation to strategic considerations; if the Irish Government have been asked for any considerations in the event of an emergency in Europe; the arrangements which the Irish Government have with the USA and/or UK Governments in the event of a nuclear emergency in Europe; if the Irish Government are informed of NATO contingency plans etc; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: The Government have not engaged and do not engage in any discussions with other Governments in relation to strategic considerations of the kind cited by the Deputy. Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the discussions he has had with the British government in the context of the Anglo-Irish Agreement in relation to the reopening of Aghalane Bridge between Cavan and Fermanagh.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: I have frequently raised the question of Aghalane Bridge with the British authorities, whose co-operation would be required if this cross-Border bridge were to be reconstructed; in their response they have referred to the security problems which would arise if this crossing point was again restored. I will continue to raise this matter with the British authorities with a view to a satisfactory solution.

As the Deputy is no doubt aware, it is not the practice to disclose details of matters raised within the context of the conference. I can assure him that in my discussions with the British authorities, I have made them fully aware of our views on cross-Border road closures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs the plans for expenditure from the Anglo-Irish Fund on industrial and infrastructural development in Belturbet and other Border towns in Cavan and Monaghan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry) Peter Barry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. P. Barry)
Speaker.P: On behalf of the Government I signed an agreement between the Irish and the British Governments for the establishment of the International Fund for Ireland on 18 September 1986. Under Article 29 of Bunreacht na hÉireann, that agreement must be approved by the Dáil before it can come into effect. I intend to introduce a motion for that purpose early in the current session. After Dáil approval of the Agreement, the Government will make an order under the Diplomatic Relations and Immunities Act, 1967, giving the fund the capacity of a body corporate in Irish law.

The Agreement establishing the fund provides for an independent board as the sole, principal organ of the fund. The Government announced the names of the board members-designate jointly with the British government on 1 October 1986. The board will be formally appointed when the necessary Irish and British parliamentary procedures regarding the establishment of the fund are completed.

It is not possible for me to answer the Deputy's question directly as decisions concerning the fund's programme are a matter for its independent board. The board, as soon as it is legally established will consider applications for assistance already submitted and invite further applications.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment (Mr. Boland) Minister for the Environment (Mr. Boland)
Speaker.P: There are no proposals before my Department at present from Tipperary (SR) County Council for the provision of individual isolated cottages. Under the present cost control procedures, housing authorities are generally not required to submit such proposals where they already have a unit cost approval for such houses from my Department. Tipperary (SR) County Council have such a unit cost approval.

In submitting their claim for capital to meet expenditure on their housing construction programme in 1986, the council sought £180,000 for nine isolated cottages that they hoped to commence in 1986. The £1.1 million capital allocation notified to the council on 31 July to meet commitments on their existing programme, catered for expenditure on two of the cottages on which work had been commenced. I will, if necessary, consider the question of making additional capital allocations in due course to finance new work (including isolated cottages) where I am satisfied that there is an established housing need and that the housing authority cannot meet any expenditure arising this year from their existing allocation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Compensation for Storm Damage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Environment if it is his intention to give a grant to Sligo County Council to help them compensate the many persons who have suffered heavy losses as a result of recent storms.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. O'Sullivan) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. O'Sullivan)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. O'Sullivan)
Speaker.P: The Government arranged that an additional £1 million would be made available to the Task Force on Special Housing Aid for the Elderly and Needy operating under the aegis of my Department for the purpose of reinstating housing affected by the severe flooding to a habitable condition. At a special meeting of the task force held on 29 August 1986 it was decided that the local authorities involved should determine the nature and level of assistance to be given in individual cases where structural repairs and basic decoration, were necessary. Expenses certified as having been incurred on this basis are recoupable to local authorities from the special provision of £1 million. At that time the local authorities, where there was evidence to hand of severe flooding in their areas, were circularised in the matter. Subsequently the position in Sligo was dealt with on the same basis following an approach to the Department by the local authority.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh)
Speaker.P: I am aware of the concern being expressed about over-fishing of coarse fish, particularly pike. Following discussions which I have had with the Central Fisheries Board, I will shortly be making a by-law which will prescribe a strict limit on the number of pike which an angler may catch and retain in any one day. Monitoring of stocks of fish in lakes and rivers is carried out by the regional fisheries boards.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry whether he has considered introducing more variety into the establishment of plantations with a view to improving their scenic aspects.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh)
Speaker.P: My Department is very conscious of the impact of forestry on the landscape and, when establishing and managing plantations, takes this into account. However, regard must also be had to such other factors as the location, setting and size of the plantation, the nature of the soil, the growth potential, edge effects etc. The potential of the site frequently limits the variety of species that can be planted but whatever opportunities present themselves for good landscaping are availed of by the Department as far as possible within the limit of such constraints and prudent silvicultural practices. Indeed, my Department has in the past been complimented in many areas for well-executed landscape work. I should add that concern with the quality of the landscape is also reflected in the content of training courses for forestry staff and, when required, specialist staff are available to advise forest managers on landscaping.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. Kavanagh)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.P: The employment of a person as a child minder is regarded for tax purposes as an application of income and not as an allowable expense incurred in the earning of that income.
As relief on the lines proposed in the Deputy's question would:

MainHeading.P: —introduce a new concept in tax reliefs,
—lead to demands for similar relief on a wide range of other personal expenditures,
—be of most benefit to those in the highest income groups.
I do not intend to alter the present treatment of such expenditure in the income tax code.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Revenue Commissioners advise me that there is no error in this case. In addition to a retirement pension the taxpayer is in receipt of an old age pension and living alone allowance from the Department of Social Welfare. All sources of income are chargeable to income tax. The social welfare payments are made gross and it is standard practice to collect the tax attributable to them by restricting the aggregate tax-free allowances under PAYE. Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance given the increased orientation at EC level towards supporting the development of regional programmes in the Community, if he considers that it is now appropriate for the Government to put much more emphasis on the creation of regional development strategies for this country; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, Ireland is treated as one region for the purposes of community regional policy. The benefits of EC support for regional development are felt, of course, in all parts of the country and the Government seek to maximise the assistance received from community sources for this purpose.

Ireland's development strategy is set out in the Government's plan Building on Reality — 1985-1987. I might add that most Government Departments and State agencies have a regional dimension to their policies and expenditure. This is particularly so in the case of the Department of Industry (in regard to its responsibilities for industrial policy and the promotion of industrial employment), the Department of the Environment (in relation to physical planning and the provision of infrastructure) and the Department of the Gaeltacht.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.P: The position is that the Government, in the light of the difficult economic situation, considered it necessary to cancel the decentralisation programme and this was announced in the context of the 1983 budget. There are no plans for the reintroduction of the decentralisation programme either in whole or in part.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Commissioners of Public Works were not in a position to purchase the site on which it is intended to construct the new employment exchange until title to the site was established by the vendor. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Incidence of AIDS Virus.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Shatter Mr. Shatter
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the total number of persons in Ireland to date who have contracted AIDS; the total number who have died from AIDS in Ireland to date; the estimated numbers of carriers infected with the AIDS virus; and the total number of persons it is projected will suffer from AIDS in Ireland by 1990.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: There have been 12 cases of AIDS in Ireland to date, of which seven have died (two of these seven cases died abroad). The latest figures show 502 positive tests for HTLV - III anti-bodies. All these positive cases have come from the identified at-risk groups.

Ireland has had a relatively small number of AIDS cases to date. The USA experience is that cases double every seven to nine months but a similar pattern is yet to emerge here. Accordingly, while the number of cases will continue to increase the potential margin of error in any projection to 1990 would be very great.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: My Department, in consultation with the Attorney General's office, is currently examining the possibility of introducing new legislation, which would provide for the seizure and confiscation of the assets of drug traffickers.

As the Deputy will appreciate, this type of legislation is quite complex and has constitutional implications. While it is not possible at present to give a date for the introduction of this necessary piece of legislation I can assure the Deputy that I regard it as a high priority and will introduce it at the earliest possible date.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the estimated shortfall in 1986 for each health board on 30 September; if he has entered negotiations with a bank to fund the health care agencies during the remainder of 1986; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the estimated shortfall of the voluntary hospitals in 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 280 and 283 together.

MainHeading.P: As the Deputy is aware the budgetary arrangements for the health services for 1986 require that expenditure be contained within the limits of approved allocations. Health boards and voluntary hospitals have been instructed accordingly and are expected to take all possible steps to achieve satisfactory budgetary results for the current year.

Some health boards and hospitals are, however, experiencing difficulties in containing expenditure within the limits of approved allocations. My Department is in close touch with these agencies on a continuing basis to ensure that all possible steps are taken to resolve the difficulties, consistent with the maintenance of emergency and other essential services.

In these circumstances the Deputy will appreciate that the budgetary outlook for the year is constantly changing and that any estimates of shortfalls at this stage would imply my acceptance that in general health agencies have reached the end of the road as regards achieving further reductions in expenditure. This I am not prepared to accept.

I have not entered into negotiations with a bank to fund health care agencies during the remainder of 1986. The traditional bank facilities are basically a matter for arrangement between the health agencies and their banks. I expect that these will be adequate to meet health agencies' requirements in 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when it is proposed to publish the details of the radical policy changes announced by the Secretary of his Department at a meeting of the World Health Organisation at Dromoland Castle.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 281 and 282 together.

The presentation made to the World Health Organisation seminar in Dromoland Castle by officers of my Department represents my views and those of the Government in relation to an evaluation of the current status of health and health services in Ireland, and assessment of present problems and an indication of the direction which health policy should take for the future. In the light of the favourable response to the policy statement from the World Health Organisation, the seminar participants and from many sources in this country, I have now decided that this preliminary statement should be developed into a consultative document for dissemination to all concerned with health in its broadest terms. This will be available shortly. I will be inviting comments on the document leading to the possibility of a broadly-based national conference on health in mid-1987.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The agreement between my Department and the FICI provides that, on average, the price of drugs on the Irish market should not exceed the trade price in the UK by more than 7.5 per cent after account is taken of currency differentials.

Under the terms of the new agreement, a price reduction of approximately 8 per cent in trade prices here took effect on 1 August last. The level of differential over UK prices is monitored on a monthly basis and, as in the previous agreement, appropriate action will be taken from time to time to ensure that the required price level is obtained, irrespective of movements in currency values.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Sir Patrick Dun's Hospital, Dublin, Closure.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the reason for the closure of Sir Patrick Dun's hospital in 1986; and if it constituted a fire hazard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The closure of Sir Patrick Dun's hospital was part of the rationalisation plan for general hospital services in Dublin. This plan which has been endorsed by successive Ministers for Health will result in the creation of a rational, cost efficient and integrated hospital system. The occupancy rate in Sir Patrick Dun's was declining for the past number of years and having regard to the fact that the building was not suitable for the provision of modern acute services the Government decided to close the hospital in 1986. The major specialist services formerly provided at Sir Patrick Dun's hospital have been incorporated into other south-city hospitals, mainly St. James's hospital. This will result in an enhanced service for the total population of south Dublin. The hospital was also, in fact a fire hazard.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if the Nuclear Energy Board reports directly to him or to officials of his Department; if he is satisfied with the method of monitoring levels of radiation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The members of the Nuclear Energy Board are appointed by the Minister for Energy. The board is financed by that Minister and is required by the terms of the Nuclear Energy Act, 1971, (No. 12 of 1971), to make an annual report to him and to submit to him such information regarding the performance of its functions as he may from time to time require.

I understand from the Minister for Energy who has prime responsibility in this area that the monitoring work undertaken by the board is of a high standard and bears comparison with similar work undertaken in other national environmental radioactivity laboratories.

Prior to Chernobyl the board operated an environmental monitoring programme principally designed to monitor the contamination of our marine environment which arose from radioactive discharges from Sellafield. When Chernobyl occurred the board was called upon to expand its monitoring activities particularly in the areas of human and animal foodstuffs and in air and water samples and was immediately granted additional resources by the Government to do this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will reconsider his decision to refuse free drugs and medicines for long term asthma sufferers, in accordance with the wishes of the Asthma Society of Ireland; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: I am not prepared to include asthma in the long term illness scheme. The cost of so doing would be at least £10 million and such additional expenditure cannot be contemplated at present. At least 40 per cent of asthma patients are covered by medical cards and those who are not so covered can avail themselves of the refund scheme, limiting monthly expenditure to £28, a limit which has not changed since January 1984. Health boards are willing to take full account of the costs attributable to asthma, and other special conditions, when assessing applications for a medical card and will also make such arrangements as may be necessary where normal operation of the refund scheme would result in hardship. I am satisfied that, in the circumstances, the service available to asthma sufferers is adequate.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bell Mr. Bell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason disability benefit was withdrawn from a person (details supplied) in County Louth; if she is aware that he was certified for disablement benefit; when he will be reinstated for disability benefit; and when arrears, if any, will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Payment of disability benefit to the person concerned was disallowed from 10 April 1986, following examination by a medical referee who expressed the opinion that he was capable of work. He appealed against the disallowance and was examined by a different medical referee who found him to be incapable of work from that date.

Accordingly payment of benefit was restored from 3 July 1986. No arrears of benefit were payable for the period from 10 April 1986 to 2 July 1986, as the person concerned was paid unemployment benefit at the same weekly rate as disability benefit during that period.

Regarding his claim for disablement benefit under the occupational injuries scheme, the position is that following an examination by a medical referee on 21 May 1986, the extent of his disablement resulting from his work accident on 2 May 1983, which previously had been assessed at 20 per cent from the commencement of his claim on 4 November 1983, was reassessed at 15 per cent for the period of eight months from 13 June 1986 to 12 February 1987. Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Andrews Mr. N. Andrews
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she is aware that as a result of the local electoral boundary changes which resulted in some parts of south Dublin being moved from Dublin Corporation to Dublin County Council control, two schools (details supplied) in the Rathfarnham area, have had school meals withdrawn after many years; and if her Department will introduce the necessary amending legislation to ensure that school meals are provided as in the past for both of these schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The school meals scheme in Dublin city is administered by Dublin Corporation under legislation which enables, but does not oblige, urban local authorities to provide school meals in their functional area.

MainHeading.P: On the alteration of the city boundary in 1985 Regulations were made extending the school meals legislation until 1 August 1986 to the areas excluded from the city and included in the county council area. This provision enabled Dublin Corporation to continue to provide meals in schools in the excluded areas, including the schools referred to in the question, and the corporation continued to do so until the end of the 1985-86 school year.

It was then decided to continue this provision indefinitely and regulations were made accordingly on 28 July 1986. Despite the enabling legislative arrangements Dublin Corporation decided not to continue providing meals on the existing basis in the two schools in question as well as three other schools in the excluded areas. There is no legislative provision under which meals can be provided in these schools other than by the corporation on the existing basis. Representations were made to the corporation by the Department but the Minister is disappointed that the corporation so far has declined to continue the provision of meals on the existing basis for the schools in question. The Department will be in further contact with the corporation in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - EEC Directive on Equal Treatment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she will clarify how the operation of the equal treatment social welfare provisions will apply to disability benefit receipents where (a) the husband is the claimant and a spouse is in employment and (b) where both husband and wife are each in receipt of disability benefit; if she will also clarify the situation regarding claims for dependent children, and the operation date of these provisions; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The Social Welfare (Amendment) Act, 1985 provided for the implementation of EEC Directive 79/7/EEC on equal treatment for men and women in matters of social security. The Act was enacted in July 1985. The revised definition of dependency under the Act is based on the principle that one spouse will be regarded as dependent on the other only if he or she is being wholly or mainly maintained by that spouse. The 1985 Act provides that a spouse in employment will not be regarded as an adult dependant. However, regulations being made under the Act will provide that where a working spouse is earning not more than £50 a week the spouse will continue to be regarded as a dependant and an adult dependant increase will be payable where the other spouse claims benefit.

MainHeading.P: The 1985 Act provides that a spouse in receipt of a social welfare benefit in his or her own right will not be regarded as an adult dependant of the other spouse. However, in the case of families where, in the week preceding implementation of the second phase of equality measures, both spouses are independently entitled to benefit, a special transitional payment of £10 a week will be made for up to one year to cushion the impact of the revised dependency conditions in these cases.

With regard to the payment of child dependent allowances, where the spouse of the claimant is regarded as an adult dependant, the full child allowances will be paid to the claimant. Where the spouse of a claimant is not an adult dependant, the claimant will be entitled to 50 per cent of the child dependant allowances. Where both spouses claim, each will be entitled to 50 per cent of the child dependant allowances. The new provisions will come into operation on 17 November, 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she will make a statement outlining her views on the theory of minimum income.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: It is assumed that the Deputy has in mind the proposal for a universal minimum flat rate payment payable to all persons, with all other income being taxed at a single rate. A guaranteed minimum income is a feature of what are known as negative income tax or social dividend schemes. Under such arrangements, low-income households are allowed to retain their pre-tax income and they may also receive a supplement of “negative tax” to bring their income up to the target income. The essential feature of both approaches is that they represent an attempt to integrate social security and taxation systems.

The Commission on Social Welfare examined such proposals and assessed their relevance as strategies for social welfare-provision in the country. The commission concluded, however, that such theories do not represent a useful approach in the Irish context, particularly because of the inherent cost of such schemes and because they constitute an inflexible method of meeting income needs.
The commission's recommendations in this area are being examined in the context of the examination of their report generally.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she will make a statement outlining her views in relation to the introduction of statutory sick pay.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The Government have been considering proposals for the overhaul of the disability benefit scheme by transferring responsibility for payment of disability benefit during an initial period to employers and have consulted the National Economic and Social Council in the matter. The council, having considered the proposal, indicated a number of areas where practical problems might arise in their implementation. In particular, concern was expressed in regard to the costs for small firms and the difficulty of ensuring that small firms would fulfil an obligation to pay statutory sick pay.

The Commission on Social Welfare considered that there are a number of positive aspects associated with the proposal but recognised also, that there are problems associated with it. The problems which have been identified are at present being examined with a view to formulating an outline scheme which would provide a basis for further discussion of the proposal with employers and trade unions.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Computerisation Programme.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the level of progress to date on computerisation within her Department; and her plans, if any, to speed up the process.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Considerable progress has been made on the Department's programme of computerisation in recent years. This progress has resulted in the introduction of improvements into the efficiency of the Department's services and has enabled it to cope with a massive increase in its workload.

MainHeading.P: With the exception of the unemployment payments schemes, practically all the Department's main schemes and services are now computerised. The number of Visual Display Units (VDUs) connected to the Department's main computer systems has grown from less than 50 in 1980 to about 800 at present and this represents about one VDU for each four of the Department's staff. It is expected that a substantial number of additional VDUs will be installed in 1987.

A computerised information system which provides information regarding benefit and pension claims for staff working in the public offices of the Department throughout the country has been developed and is being expanded. Visual Display Units linked to the central computers have been installed in the major public offices in Dublin and in a number of information offices outside Dublin.

A major programme of further computerisation is envisaged of which the major development will be the extension of computerised facilities to the Department's services outside of Dublin. This will require careful planning and a large investment of resources and for these reasons will take a number of years to complete.

The commission also made recommendations about the provision of more information to claimants in connection with decisions and appeals. The implications of the approach recommended by the commission in this regard are at present being examined and proposals will be put to the Government in due course.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Income Support for Families.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the present position in relation to the implementation of the Government's policy, as outlined in Building on Reality, 1985-1987 to abolish the family income supplement; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. McCarthy Dr. McCarthy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare her views on the introduction of an additional payment equivalent to the weekly value of the child dependant allowance paid on a quarterly basis for families long term dependent on social welfare as recommended by the Commission on Social Welfare.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 374 and 375 together.

The recommendations made by the Commission on Social Welfare in the area of income support for families include proposals that child dependant increases with social welfare payments should be retained and rationalised into one payment for all child dependants of social welfare recipients and that additional payments be made on a quarterly basis for families long term dependent on social welfare payments.
The commission also recommends differentiation of child benefit rates by age and family size and the retention of the family income supplement scheme.

The commission's recommendations in this area are relatively complex and the approach they recommend would differ from the approach outlined by the Government in the National Plan Building on Reality, 1985-1987. The commission's proposals in this area are under examination at present and proposals will be put to the Government in this matter in due course.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Disadvantaged Areas Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the income limit for part time farmers to qualify for sheep and cattle headage payments in the disadvantaged areas in each of the ten EC member states.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Part time farmers in the disadvantaged areas of Belgium, Greece, Italy and the Netherlands and in the disadvantaged areas of France other than mountain areas must earn at least 50 per cent of their income from farming and spend more than 50 per cent of their working time at farming to qualify for sheep and cattle headage payments. In the disadvantaged mountain areas of France the income of part time farmers must not exceed twice the minimum social welfare income level.

In Germany, farmers whose combined farm and off-farm incomes exceed a certain level do not qualify for payment. In certain German lander, part time farmers whose off-farm income exceeds a certain level are also excluded from payment. In Rhineland-Pfalz, for example, the combined income cannot exceed 20,953 ECU and the off-farm income cannot exceed 12,578 ECU.

MainHeading.P: In Luxembourg all farmers qualify for payment but full-time farmers receive a supplementary payment of 22 ECUs per livestock unit which part-time farmers are not paid. In Ireland, of course, the combined incomes of applicant and spouse must not exceed £6,400 if the applicant is to qualify for cattle and/or sheep headage payments. The United Kingdom, Spain and Portugal do not as yet take off-farm income into account when determining eligibility for such payments. Denmark does not pay compensatory allowances to farmers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The distribution of flexi-milk is only relevant in the case of co-operatives and other purchasers which exceeded their quotas. In the case of purchasers who do not exceed their quotas such distribution does not arise because none of their suppliers are liable for super-levy. MainHeading.P: In 1985-86 four categories of producers qualified for priority in flexi-milk allocations. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Transfer of Women Prisoners.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if it is intended to open a women's prison in the grounds of the Central Mental Hospital, Dundrum, Dublin; if he is satisfied that this development will not interfere with the present facilities of the hospital; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to my reply to Question No. 58 on 27 February.

MainHeading.P: At the time I referred to an announcement in January by my predecessor and the Minister for Health that a new unit in the grounds of the Central Mental Hospital would, when completed, be transferred to my Department for the use of the prison service. I indicated that the broad purpose of the unit's transfer was to enable facilities to be provided to treat offenders with medical-related problems in modern and hygienic conditions and that, for the foreseeable future, it would be used to cater primarily for female offenders.

Such a move will involve the transfer to the unit of many of the women currently located in Mountjoy and a number from Limerick prison. Because of the small size of the female offender population and the large proportion of them who have medical and related problems the transfer to the unit will mean that there will no longer be any need to accommodate female offenders in Mountjoy. Conditions for female offenders at the prison have been unsatisfactory for some time and the difficulties there have been greatly intensified by the increase in medical and related problems among female offenders.

The regime at the new unit, however, will be different from that which has operated traditionally at the women's prisons and the emphasis at the unit will be on using the extensive modern facilities there to enable the needs of the female offenders, and particularly requirements arising from medical and related problems, to be coped with in a manner which is not possible in the existing traditional prison settings. Accordingly, it would be entirely misleading to characterise the new unit as being a replacement for Mountjoy Prison.

I should make it clear, however, that while, given the nature of the problems of the offenders who will be accommodated at the unit, emphasis will have to be placed on the medical services available to them the unit will not, in any sense, be a hospital. The traditional arrangements whereby the health board provides hospitalisation for offenders in need of it will continue. The women in the unit will be there because of decisions by the courts to confine them in custody and the role of the unit will be to confine them in conditions which can take account of their medical and related needs in a manner which is not possible in a traditional prison setting.

It will be clear, therefore, that while there are factors of security and health involved in both the Central Mental Hospital and the new unit the institutions will fulfill very different roles and, in these circumstances, it is intended that the unit will be run entirely separately from the hospital. To facilitate this it is proposed in the course of a few months to erect a wall around the unit to completely separate it from the rest of the hospital grounds and to provide a separate entrance to it in the perimiter wall (it is hoped that it might be possible initially to run the unit to a limited extent without these works being in place but this is a matter which requires further consideration and discussion).

The relationship between the unit and the hospital would essentially be one of “good neighbours”. The unit will form part of the prison service and will be operated by my Department. The hospital will continue to be run by the Eastern Health Board. Prison service staff will not be involved in the operation of the hospital and, equally, hospital staff will not be involved in the operation of the unit. In practical terms the only connection the unit will have with the hospital is that it is located (separately) in the same grounds and that heating etc. supplies will be shared.

In the circumstances, there are no grounds for suggesting that the use of the unit by the prison service will interfere in any way with the existing services to patients at the hospital. As I have indicated the institutions will be physically divided and operate separately. The specific security requirements relating to the unit will not impinge on the patients of the hospital and are not expected to be any more intensive in kind than those which already apply in respect of the hospital itself. Indeed, in relation to some individual patients who have attended the hospital the level of security which has been applied to them has been far higher than anything envisaged as appropriate for any of the women who will be housed in the unit.
Given the difficulties at present in providing appropriate facilities for many of the women in custody I am anxious that the transfer of the unit should proceed as quickly as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Prison Staff Overtime.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the actual expenditure on prison overtime up to 30 September 1986, and the estimated total for the full year; the average overtime per prison officer, and the maximum paid, together with the corresponding hours of overtime worked in each case; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: Expenditure on prison overtime to end September 1986 was £9,790,739 inclusive of £741,152 arising from the payment of arrears under the terms of a “special” pay award to prison staff. Total expenditure for the full year is estimated at £13.40 million.

Based on expenditure to the end of September and the average number of prison staff of all grades serving during that period the average overtime per prison officer for the nine months is £5,572. This corresponds to an average of about 590 hours overtime per officer or 15 hours per week. I should emphasise that these figures are averages and that levels of overtime vary between individuals and from prison to prison.

Details of the maximum overtime earnings this year are not available at this stage and their calculation would take up a disproportionate amount of staff time. In 1985, the maximum payment was £20,336.39.
I am conscious of the need to keep overtime working to a minimum. Only essential overtime is worked and this is closely monitored in my Department.

MainHeading.P: Following a recent thorough review of prison staffing needs the Government has approved 184 new posts in the prison service. Recruitment to fill these vacancies is now proceeding and most of the vacancies will be filled by trained staff by the end of this year. I expect that the recruitment of these additional staff will have an impact on reducing overtime expenditure in 1987 and following years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: In the National Plan Building on Reality 1985-1987 the Government committed up to £1 million for adult education by 1987, directed primarily towards the provision of courses to overcome illiteracy and towards the development of community education. Speaker.P: The contract documents for the building of a new national school at Foxford, County Mayo have now been prepared. My Department will at the earliest opportunity be in communication with the school authorities regarding the invitation of tenders for the project. It is not possible at this stage to say when a tender would be accepted.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will make a statement on the present position in relation to the new Ballycastle national school in view of the conditions that exist in the existing building.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: A sketch scheme for the proposed new national school at Ballycastle, County Mayo, has been prepared by my Department's professional staff and referred to the chairman of the school's board of management for purposes of obtaining local authority planning permission. A grant will be formally sanctioned towards the cost of the project when agreement has been reached with the school authorities regarding an appropriate local contribution towards the cost.

MainHeading.P: When these matters have been finalised, the next stage of architectural planning will be the preparation of the contract documents.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when a contract will be placed for necessary extensions and improvements to Crossmolina girls' national school, County Mayo; and if he will make a statement on the situation there.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has approved plans for, and has sanctioned a grant towards the cost of, an extension to Crossmolina girls' national school, County Mayo. The detail design work is at present being undertaken by the school's own architect and the submission of working drawing for examination by my Department is awaited. The question of placing a contract does not arise as yet, and I am not in a position to say when this will take place. An application by the school for a grant towards the cost of improvements to the existing building is under consideration, and my Department will communicate a decision in the matter as soon as possible to the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position in relation to the request from Mayo VEC for extensions to Lacken Cross vocational schoos; and if he will make a statement on when it is expected that building will commence there.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department awaits submission of working drawings by the County Mayo Vocational Education Committee in respect of the proposed extension to Lacken Cross vocational school. At this stage it would not be possible to say when building is likely to commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will make a statement in relation to the apparent stalemate concerning the extension to Crossmolina vocational school, County Mayo; and if he is in a position to state when sanction will be given to proceed to tender.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has recently completed examination of the developed sketch scheme proposals submitted in respect of the extension to Crossmolina vocational school. There has been no avoidable delay in this examination.

A letter will issue shortly to the County Mayo Vocational Education Committee outlining a basis for proceeding to the next stage of the design process. The question of when tenders may be invited cannot arise for consideration until the design process has been satisfactorily completed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the date for the signing of contracts for extensions to Breaffy national school, Ballina, County Mayo; and if he will make a statement on the up-to-date position in relation to the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: Tenders for the proposed extension to Breaffy national school, Ballina, County Mayo are being examined by my Department. It will not be possible to set a date for the placing of a contract for the project until the 1987 capital allocation for national schools building has been settled.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the present position regarding national schools (details supplied) in County Donegal awaiting reconstruction, extension or replacement.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The position with regard to the ten County Donegal national schools referred to in the Deputy's question is as follows: in two cases (Commons, Alt) building grants have not yet been sanctioned although the applications have been accepted in principle for grant scheme purposes, in four cases (Lettermacaward, Convoy, Fintra, Drumkeen) the contract documents are in course of preparation, in three cases (Dore, Niall Mór, Belcruit) the question of inviting tenders is now arising for consideration and in the remaining case (Ballydevitt) the question of preparing a contract is about to arise for consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when final approval will be given and works will commence on the extension to a primary school (details supplied) on the border of counties Carlow-Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: Sketch plans for the extension to the school referred to by the Deputy have been approved and a grant was formally sanctioned on 23 July 1986 towards the project. Contract documents are now in course of preparation. It is not possible at this stage to say when work on the extension will commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Financial Aid for School Exchanges.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bell Mr. Bell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he has any plans to give financial support to Drogheda VEC in their application for a grant for the purpose of the visit of Northern Ireland school children to Our Lady's, Green Hill and St. Laurence community college, Drogheda, and St. Oliver's community college, Drogheda, County Louth; the amount of such grants; when they will be paid; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: There are no funds available to my Department at present from which financial assistance could be paid in respect of school exchanges.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position concerning the provision of a physical education hall for St. Mac Dara's College, Willington, Dublin 12.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to the last paragraph of my reply to him on 4 March last.

My Department is at present engaged in the review mentioned in that reply. The case for the provision of a physical education hall in St. Mac Dara's College will be considered in the context of the review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position concerning the provision of a primary school at Castle View, Tallaght.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has had recent discussions with the chairman of the board of management of the Castle View national school, Tallaght, County Dublin, regarding the provision of ten further classrooms to accommodate additional enrolments expected in September next and onwards, and to replace temporary prefabricated classrooms already in use at the school. The planning process for the building is in hands.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Walsh Mr. S. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position concerning the provision of a physical education hall for Killinarden community school, Tallaght, Dublin 24.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: A physical education hall has been approved for Killinarden community school, and it was intended that it be constructed to a standard plan which had already been prepared by my Department's consultants. Following the completion earlier this year of the first halls constructed in accordance with the standard plan, it was decided that a number of improvements should be incorporated in all future halls. The documentation is currently being revised to incorporate these improvements and as soon as the revisions are completed, tenders will be invited for the Killinarden project.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Education the date of final sanction of a post-primary school at Kingscourt, County Cavan; the date for inviting tenders; and the estimated date for the commencement of construction.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The submission of a developed sketch scheme is awaited from County Cavan Vocational Education Committee. At this stage it would not be possible to say when tenders will be invited or construction commenced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McEllistrim Mr. McEllistrim
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position regarding the extension to Curranes national school, Castleisland, County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The preparation of the contract documents for the extension to Curranes national school, Castleisland, County Kerry is now at an advanced stage. When this work is completed, the question of the invitation of tenders for the project will arise for consideration and a decision on the matter will be conveyed at the earliest opportunity to the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the reason the five community based groups, members of the umbrella group network for jobs, have been refused grants under the Teamwork scheme; and if their applications will be reviewed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Four of the applications referred to were not considered as they had already been approved for a planning grant from the Youth Employment Agency under which a feasibility study is being carried out at present regarding the commencial potential of the proposals contained in the applications.

The fifth proposal, involving the publication of a magazine for the over 55's was rejected for a number of reasons. The application failed to meet the criteria for grant aid under the Teamwork scheme including those relating to the non-commercial nature of projects. There are no plans for any of the applications to be reviewed under Teamwork.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Employment Schemes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if the commitment given to the Stoneybatter and District Youth and Community Council in June 1986, to allow them to employ 20 people and one full time supervisor will be honoured under the social employment scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: There are, at present, eleven workers and one full time supervisor employed on the Stoneybatter and District Youth and Community Council project under the social employment scheme. Due to the success of the scheme the Government's target of 10,000 participants was surpassed in June of this year and the budget is committed. As a result, participation quotas have been assigned to each of the National Manpower Service regions. As the number of participants has to be maintained within these quotas, I regret that it is not possible to increase the numbers employed on the Stoneybatter project at present. The matter is, however, under constant review by the National Manpower Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McGinley Mr. McGinley
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will give details of social employment schemes approved for County Donegal during 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Statistics relating to the social employment scheme are compiled on the basis of National Manpower Service regions.

Details on individual counties will be available as soon as the records of the scheme are fully computerised. In the north west region, which encompasses counties Sligo, Leitrim and Donegal, there are currently 233 projects in operation employing 1,397 persons.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if it is his intention in view of the very high rate of unemployment in the north west to seek an increase in the allocation for the social employment scheme for these areas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The ambitious target of 10,000 participants set by the Government for the social employment scheme was surpassed in June 1986 and the budget is committed. It has become necessary, therefore to maintain rather than increase participation levels. Accordingly, participant quotas have now been assigned to each of the National Manpower Service regions, whereby recruitment to the scheme may occur only where sufficient participants are terminating their period of employment under the scheme.

The north west region of the National Manpower Service encompasses counties Sligo, Leitrim and Donegal. There are currently 233 social employment scheme projects operating in the region employing 1,397 persons which represents 15 per cent of the total participation in the scheme. There are no plans at present to increase the SES allocation for the north west or any other region.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Prendergast Mr. Prendergast
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will give details of the numbers employed in social employment schemes in Limerick city and county since the introduction of the scheme; the amount of wages paid to those employed and the amount of Government grants paid to the projects concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Social employment scheme statistics on an individual county basis will be available as soon as the records system for the scheme is fully computerised. At present information is only available on the basis of National Manpower Service regions.
Limerick city and county are part of the National Manpower Service's midwest region, which also comprises counties Clare and Limerick (NR).

Participation on the SES reached a peak of 1,116 persons in the mid west region in August 1986. Approximately £5.9 million has been allocated in respect of wages, materials and supervision to projects in the region. At present there are 894 people employed in 249 projects in the region.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the reason a social employment scheme project has not been sanctioned for a primary school (details supplied) in County Wexford in view of the fact that a written commitment was given by the NMS that they could commence on 1 September.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The application in question was approved in December 1985. However, the sponsors decided, at their own initiative, not to proceed with recruitment at that time. At a later stage the sponsors indicated their intention of starting the project on 1 September 1986. No written commitment to commence on that date was given by the National Manpower Service of my Department.

MainHeading.P: Due to the success of the scheme the budget is committed. In the circumstances, participation quotas for each of the eight manpower regions had to be introduced last June. As a result, it had not been possible to start any new projects in the south east region pending the completion of existing ones. I am happy to be able to inform the House, however, that it is now possible to recruit persons to the social employment scheme in the south east within these quota restrictions. The post in question is one of a number in respect of which permission to proceed will be granted immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the total amount of grants paid under (a) the employment incentive scheme and (b) the work experience programme, to firms established under the business development scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The Business Expansion Scheme — also known as the Business Development Scheme — provides tax relief for individuals on money invested for specific purposes and is operated by the Revenue Commissioners. Companies in receipt of grants under the employment incentive scheme and the work experience programme operated by the Department of Labour can also qualify under the business expansion scheme. As the information sought is not compiled for qualifying purposes, I regret that I cannot be of any assistance to the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Manning Mr. Manning
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he has established the cause of the recent explosion at Guinness's Brewery; and if his Department are happy that steps are being taken to ensure that, as far as possible, there is no recurrence of such an explosion.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The incident has been the subject of continuing investigation by the industrial inspectorate of my Department. Due to the many complex factors involved it has not yet been possible to reach a conclusion about the cause of the explosion. When the findings of the investigation become available the industrial inspectorate will issue advice on measures necessary to avoid such explosions.
